lesson.name: Part 3: Note Taking; Using Accessing Texts Online (primarily for instructors)

page.title: The Importance of Listening or Reading and Note Taking
page.contents:
Parrish and Johnson (2010) found that few teachers give adult ELLs practice with note-taking skills in their classes

Why is note taking so important?

  • Keeps learners focused on the task.
  • Increases comprehension and retention.
  • Helps organize ideas.
  • Provides prompts for later review.

Why can note taking pose challenges for adult ELLs? Think about that question before continuing.

page.title: Why Can Note Taking Pose Challenges for Adult English Language Learners?
page.contents:
Adult ELLs may have the following characteristics:

  • Lack prior formal schooling
  • Lack sufficient writing skills
  • Have difficulties with multitasking: Attending to listening or reading while also writing notes
  • Lack knowledge of note-taking strategies

We can scaffold the note-taking process in many ways from the earliest ELA levels. Before turning to an overview of strategies, write a few ideas on any ways you have your students practice note taking, even in small ways.

page.title: Common Activities That Scaffold Note Taking: K-W-L Charts
page.contents:
K-W-L Charts
What do I think I know? What do I want to learn? What did I learn?

K-W-L Charts: What do I think I know, what do I want to learn, what did I learn?

  • Activates prior knowledge and acknowledges what the learner already knows and brings to the task.
  • Promotes goal setting and personalizes the task.
  • Assesses learned knowledge.

All this promotes active listening or reading beyond questions in a book and gives learners a focused note-taking task.

NOTE: Some teachers add a Q column: What questions do I still have?

page.title: Grid Activities
page.contents:
Listen to three people talk about differences between their culture and countries where they have lived. Write the missing information in the boxes.

Group A
Where did the person live?What is the practice or custom?How is it different in their own country?How do they feel about the practice?
Julia In the US, cars watch out for people walking in the street. Fireworks are very far from a crowd.
Betsy Children and parents spend more time together. She really likes that custom.
Sina The United States

What is the purpose of using grid-fill tasks while listening or reading?

  • Provides practice with document literacy (charts and tables at school and at work).
  • Encourages listening and reading for specific information and then noting those key ideas.
  • Limits the amount of information learners can write (i.e., not full sentences).
  • Is ideal for multilevel classes (learners write as much or as little as they can).

All this promotes active listening or reading beyond questions in a book and gives learners a focused note-taking task.

page.title: Graphic Organizers
page.contents:
What is the purpose of providing a graphic organizer that matches the text structure?

  • Gives learners tools or templates for organizing information.
  • Promotes deeper reading, listening, and thinking.
  • Provides tools for building learner autonomy as they choose which graphic organizer works best for them.

All this promotes active listening or reading beyond questions in a book and gives learners a focused note-taking task.

Note how graphic organizers were used in the videos:

  • T-chart: compare and contrast; pros/cons
  • Tree diagram: categorizing information

View a chart that matches text types and genres to graphic organizers.

page.title: Cornell Notes
page.contents:
Personality and birth-order theory

TITLE

I. Origin of the theory
II. First born Characteristics
bossy
Famous people
III. Middle child Characteristics
IV. Only child Characteristics
V. Last born Characteristics
like attention; carefree
The Theory
Summary:

Cornell Notes (Pauk, 2001) are a guided note-taking system where learners divide their paper into three sections: one for key points, one for notes, and one for a summary. These notes can help learners in the following ways:

  • Recognize the main idea.
  • Identify supporting details.
  • Practice summarizing.
  • Review, reflect on, and study from notes.

Teachers can start by giving partially completed Cornell Notes as a scaffold for practicing the technique.

Here's a sample that students could use in George's lesson on the birth-order theory shown in an earlier video.

page.title: Reading and Listening to Texts Online
page.contents:
Adult ELLs can work on reading and listening skills while also making use of digital tools and resources. This section provides sample activities that apply the strategies from this unit as learners go online to find the texts. Remember these guidelines when choosing Web resources (or for learners to use as they evaluate resources online):

  • Accuracy. Does the webpage list the author and the institution that published the page and provide contact information?
  • Authority. Does the page list the author credentials and have one of the following domains: .edu, .gov, .org, or .net?
  • Objectivity. Does the page provide accurate information with limited advertising?
  • Currency. Is the page current and updated regularly (as stated on the page)?
  • Coverage. Can you view the information properly--not limited to fees, browser technology, or software requirement?

(Cornell University, 2014)

page.title: Reading for Information Online: Career Explorations
page.contents:
The National College Transitions Network (2009) developed Integrating Career Awareness Into the ABE [Adult Basic Education] and Adult ESOL Classroom (Used for the purposes of this online course with permission from the National College Transition Network at World Education, Inc.), a curriculum for exploring careers. Activities in the curriculum would be appropriate for advanced-level adult ELLs and include practice with many reading strategies:

  • Reading for specific information
  • Reading and interpreting charts and graphs
  • Comparing information

Many activities provide opportunities for learners to develop effective communication skills by exchanging the data they found for a particular profession. They can work on problem solving by determining which careers are most prevalent in their area and also consider the required training needs.

page.title: Reading for Information Online: Career Explorations
page.contents:
Students can visit the U.S. Department of Labor website, careeronestop.org, or a state website. The class should work through one or two professions as a whole class.

Look at the three tasks from the curriculum. What reading strategies do these activities promote? How could you modify them if they are not appropriate for the level you teach? The tasks look at several dimensions of career exploration. Which dimensions could you start with for less advanced learners?

  • Reading grid: Used while exploring career opportunities at the website
  • Questions to ask a partner: Used while interviewing a partner about they found
  • Information exchange grid: Used while recording what they learn from colleagues in class

page.title: Listening for Information Online: ChooseMyPlate.gov
page.contents:
This online video has some interesting benefits for adult ELLs:

  • Depicts an immigrant working as the chef for the White House.
  • Proposes a menu that may resonate with learners from many backgrounds.
  • Includes concepts that can lead to interesting conversations and some critical thinking (mindful eating).

This lesson is based on the Choose My Plate video: 5 Food Group Stir Fry
5 Food Group Stir Fry

U.S. Department of Agriculture

Listen to audio:

ELL_MOD1_UNIT3_0190.mp3

Audio transcript


Many ELA curricula include units on healthy living and nutrition. The problem is that we are evaluating what is “healthy” or “nutritious” though our own lens. The latest government guidelines focus on variety of foods and portion sizes. This online video has some interesting benefits for adult ELLs: It depicts an immigrant working as the chef for the White House. It proposes a menu that may resonate with learners from many backgrounds. It also includes concepts that can lead to interesting conversations and some critical thinking, for example, portion sizes and mindful eating. The activities that follow are suitable for use with other authentic online video clips or podcasts.

page.title: Lesson Activities: ChooseMyPlate.gov
page.contents:
• In small groups, match pictures to the food name.
  • Call out a food name and ask learners to stand on a continuum according to eating the food:
Often Sometimes Never

  • Make predictions: What can I cook with these foods?
  • Listen to the first three minutes and choose pictures of foods that are mentioned. Also identify any match to their predictions.
  • Listen again to whole video and complete a linear string with steps for making stir fry.
  • Follow-up discussion questions:
    • The cooks talk about portion size. What is it and how reasonable is it? Why is portion size important?
    • What do they say about mindful eating? Why do they think mindful eating is important?

page.title: Lesson Analysis Task
page.contents:
Now answer the following questions about the ChooseMyPlate.gov lesson:

What listening strategies are practiced? What other skills are included (higher order thinking, note taking)?

What task types are used (sorting, matching, graphic organizers) and how do these help give learners practice with the strategies you identified?

What did you see in the lesson you reviewed that you could use or adapt in your own class (the content or the techniques and activities)?

page.title: Application for Instructors: Using Simple Nonfiction Reading Texts and Listening Passages With Beginners and Beyond
page.contents:
How can you apply the principles in this unit to a variety of levels and topics? Choose one lesson to review using the questions that follow.

A Family's Day (Beginning)

  • Using a linear string organizer
  • Transferring information to a grid
  • Sequencing, organizing, and analyzing information

Cities of the World (Beginning)

  • Using grid fill-in while reading
  • Jigsaw reading

The Science of Happiness (Advanced)

  • Jigsaw reading
  • Using graphic organizers
  • Interviewing and data collection
  • Synthesizing information

Although these all focus on reading, the same principles and task types can be used with listening passages.

page.title: Lesson Analysis Task (required for instructors)
page.contents:
As you review the reading or listening lesson you chose, answer the following questions. If you are working with colleagues, do your own jigsaw task, each reviewing and sharing what you learned about a different lesson. 

What reading or listening strategies are practiced? What other skills are included (higher order thinking, note taking)?

What task types are used (jigsaw, graphic organizers, grids) and how do these help give learners practice with the strategies you identified?

What did you see in the lesson you reviewed that you could use or adapt in your own class (the content or the techniques and activities)?

page.title: Applying the Principles in Your Setting
page.contents:
Now choose a short authentic reading or listening passage and create one or two activities that you could use with the learners you serve. For podcasts suitable for adult ELLs, see http://elllo.org.

Consider the following:

  • A prereading or listening activity to activate learners' prior knowledge about the topic
  • A graphic organizer suitable for the text type
  • The jigsaw approach to promote interaction among learners

If you are working with colleagues, present what you create to others in your group.

Listen to audio:

ELL_MOD1_UNIT3_0200.mp3

Audio transcript


Now it is your chance to apply what you have learned in the unit to a reading text or a listening passage of your choosing. If you would like to incorporate more listening practice, this is the time to visit http://elllo.org, where you will find more than 1,000 short podcasts on a variety of topics. You could choose two or three on a similar topic and create a jigsaw activity. If you want to focus on reading, look for a short article, work document, or community brochure that adult ELLs may encounter. The following are some things to consider. Try a prereading or listening activity to activate learners’ prior knowledge about the topic. Consider a graphic organizer suitable for the text type; perhaps you can try the jigsaw approach to promote interaction among learners. If you are working with colleagues, present what you create to others. And try it out in your class to see how learners respond.

page.title: Final Reflection (required for instructors)
page.contents:
Now reflect on your current understanding of the benefits of using nonfiction texts at all levels, as well as the need to create tasks to develop reading and listening strategies. Share this with others if you are working through the unit with colleagues.

What are three reasons why we need to include more nonfiction, informational texts, and authentic listening passages with adult ELLs?

What are the primary listening and reading needs of your learners (if prepared in Unit 1, look at the vignette you prepared)? How can you address some of those based on what you learned in this unit?

 

You have reached the end of this lesson.  You may review any of the content in this lesson using the Lesson Menu on the left of the screen.

If you have finished viewing the lesson, (1) click the NEXT button on this screen to indicate completion in your progress tracker.  Then, (2) return to the home page to select your next activity.  Activities you have completed will be checked off in your progress tracker.
